title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Wesco Aircraft Slumps; Puerto Rico Advisers Face New Disclosure Rules
text:
A Boeing factory in Renton, Wash. The Covid-19 pandemic took a toll on new airplane demand.

Wesco Aircraft faces cash crunch as depressed plane orders weigh on earnings. Wesco Aircraft Holdings Inc., a distributor of airplane parts that does business as Incora, faces a cash crunch as depressed demand for new airplanes weighs on earnings and the company grapples with a high debt load. Wesco's cash dwindled to just enough to cover an interest payment it made this week, while another big interest payment is due in May, according to people familiar with the matter.

Senate advances Puerto Rico bankruptcy disclosure rules. Congress took a major step Thursday toward enacting bipartisan legislation that would require McKinsey & Co. and other firms and professionals steering Puerto Rico through bankruptcy to disclose potential conflicts of interest.

Share this email with a friend.

Bankruptcy

Virgin Islands refinery buyer wins Limetree Bay auction. St. Croix Energy LLLP has claimed victory in an auction to sell the shuttered Limetree Bay Refinery in the U.S. Virgin Islands, according to the buyer. St. Croix Energy was named as the leading bidder to buy the crude-processing facility on Sunday with a $20 million cash bid, increased from its initial offer of $11.5 million.

Little is known about the buyer except that its backers have roots in the U.S. Virgin Islands and was recently incorporated. People familiar with the matter said the court-supervised auction process is still ongoing as the estate looks for a backup bid in case the winner is unable to complete the purchase. â€” Alexander Saeedy

White Collar

Patients describe alarming test results at Elizabeth Holmes trial. Jurors in the criminal-fraud trial of Elizabeth Holmes heard from two patients who took Theranos Inc. blood tests that returned troubling results: one who believed she could be HIV-positive and another whose results could have been a sign of prostate cancer.

International

Unfinished buildings at an Evergrande development last month.

Evergrande China Evergrande to shed stake in Tencent-backed venture for $273 million. Cash-strapped property giant China Evergrande Group said it will sell its entire stake in a company that provides online video-streaming and Internet home services for the equivalent of $273 million, closing a chapter in a six-year business venture with internet behemoth Tencent Holdings Ltd.

In Other News

Student loan forgiveness is excluded from Democrats' $2 trillion spending bill. (CNBC)
